> nit: probably should use a kwarg

I'll defer to your judgement here, but I'd like to propose another way of doing this.

The idea of keeping track of "dependency builders" that are decided up front seems against the flow. I think it'd be easier to make that decision down here (like it was before) and split into two different methods:

1) Build chart dependencies using the "Armada way" i.e. chart documents
2) Build chart dependencies using the "Helm way" i.e. charts dir

In the future, if we add support for .tgz or requirements files, I think it'd be easier to expand on then the current implementation.

With that being said, I'm okay with this approach should you decide to stick with it.

Not sure I understand. The change made here should make things more configurable, not less, via dependency injection of `dependency_builders` (lol, referring to different "dependency"s there). So essentially the default way is now the "Helm way", but you can override that with the "Armada way" if you want by injecting dependency builders into the ChartBuilder. This way, ChartBuilder requires no knowledge of the "Armada way". I added a separate constructor for the "helm way" as well now just to make it fully externalized.

The .tgz support is just a matter of extracting .tgz's in `charts`, when they exist. Helm CLI does this in memory, Armada will need to extract into a persistent directory, including tying into the chart caching that is in place.

The requirements files don't factor in, as they a build-time concept used by `helm dep up` to populate the `charts` directory.

> The requirements files don't factor in, as they a build-time
 > concept used by `helm dep up` to populate the `charts` directory.

I didn't realize they were separate; thanks for the explanation.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Please remove - line numbers do not convey much meaning to tests

Please take a look at commit message conventions here: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages

The header line of the commit message should be <50 characters when possible. It allows short logs to be more meaningful.. It's usually a challenge to limit something to 50 characters, especially if the change is harder to implement or explain - but this convention tries to reimpose the project's development ideology - simple, single-intent changes :)

This isn't the content of the commit though :(

 

It should still be "Validate share quota after updating"

 

With Gerrit, you don't need to make intermediate commits and squash-and-merge like is usually the workflow with pull requests - you can amend/overwrite your previous commits; when the change merges, it is done as a single commit, and your intermediate patches aren't merged into the repository. 

Take a look at the diff in the UI, between "Base" and the latest patchset, that's what merging this change will update the repository with.

Thank you, I get it now. It's that there are a class of protocols that all come down to being TCP or UDP.

The goal is to raise exception when 2 protocols that share the same l4 protocol, use the same port (we want to allow 2 listeners such as udp:53 and tcp:53, but also we want to detect when 2 listeners use tcp:80 and http:80 in the same LB), I don't know if we can do this using only a constraint.

To avoid this query, we could add a `l4_protocol` in the listener table that could be only one of UDP or TCP (so for HTTP/HTTPS/TCP/etc.. listeners), and use this field in the constraint.
If we flip this to a dict, {constants.PROTOCOL_HTTP: constants.PROTOCOL_TCP} we can avoid looping over this list by doing a simple dict lookup. Though this might make the later lookup harder.
I flipped the dict and changed the code, now we loop over protocols only if the load balancer has multiple listeners that share the same port.

 > do want to do upgrade?

Good catch and good point. Fixed.
If package installation requires to perform system reboot, what do we do? Can be checked by presence of /var/run/reboot-required file or running needrestart cmd.
If system upgrade requires to perform system reboot, what do we do? Can be checked by presence of /var/run/reboot-required file or running needrestart cmd.

> At least a notification in logs, please. 

Done.


> add label "needs-reboot" to the node) - it's a design question.

This is a neat idea; I like it. However:

1) If the label is never removed, then it can remain forever, even after a node has rebooted.

2) I'm not sure if this daemonset has the means to label a node, and adding support for that is out of the scope of this change.

> If system upgrade requires to perform system reboot, what do we do?
 > Can be checked by presence of /var/run/reboot-required file or
 > running needrestart cmd.

Are you requesting notification that a reboot is required, or asking for divingbell to reboot the hosts requiring reboot? I can add a notification, but Divingbell should not reboot any nodes joined to a K8s cluster as a part of day 2 operations. That would be incredibly risky.
At least a notification in logs, please. Whether to reboot or not, or do anything else (e.g. add label "needs-reboot" to the node) - it's a design question.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: This is due to the switch to "include_tasks" because of the depreciation of "include" in ansible.  Those two statements don't have the same behavior regarding tags.

Import_tasks was used for non looping statement (static) during the migration, while "include_tasks" was used for looping statement (dynamic).

The solution for include_tasks is to append the always tag as seen https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/30882#issuecomment-380596557

common/deploy-steps.j2.message: this seems unrelated to the change, or missing an explanation in the commit msg?
Ack, I guess this isn't needed as when we execute the minor update we're already in RHEL8. I'll remove it, thanks for the review.
so here "import_tasks" is used, wondering if that isn't the "right" solution.
why do we need to repeat this ?
considering the behavior of include_tasks, I'm wondering if we don't introduce unwanted side effect.
Not tag here so this should be ok.  But this is not in sync we all the other external task, maybe it's legit, don't know yet.
so wasn't import_tasks the rigth solution here as well ?

As discussed in #rhos-upgrades irc channel, the reason to change from include into include/import_tasks was that include got depreacted from Ansible 2.4. include_tasks has a different handling of the tags compared to import_tasks, so you're right that the easy solution here would have been using import_tasks. However, you can't use import_tasks in a loop (you'll get -> ERROR! You cannot use loops on 'import_tasks' statements. You should use 'include_tasks' instead.) Being that the main reason why the include got changed into include_tasks. Now, the only way to preserve the tasks execution when having an include_tasks, seems to be passing tags: always, as explained in this github issue: https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/30882#issuecomment-380596557.
This explains why adding tags: always let's us execute the tasks within external_upgrade_steps_tasks.yaml and not external_update_steps_tasks.yaml (which was missing it).

openstack_dashboard/dashboards/identity/.message: It's not, because unescaped parens have meaning inside a regular expression.
Can you please elaborate on what you mean by "not need"?
I think adding escape characters here is superfluous

Don't we need 'r' prefix before the second string?
According to my test below, the first and second strings are evaluated separately and then concatenated.
I guess you use raw strings for regular expression but the second string is not a raw string in the current version.

$ python2.7
Python 2.7.15+ (default, Nov 27 2018, 23:36:35) 
[GCC 7.3.0] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> r'\a' r'\b' == r'\a\b'
True
>>> r'\a' '\b' == r'\a\b'
False
>>> 

$ python3  
Python 3.6.8 (default, Jan 14 2019, 11:02:34) 
[GCC 8.0.1 20180414 (experimental) [trunk revision 259383]] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> r'\a' r'\b' == r'\a\b'
True
>>> r'\a' '\b' == r'\a\b'
False
>>>
Well, we don't need r in any of them, since I removed all the backslashes anyways.

This will handle only a specific exception i.e. PasswordRequirementsValidationError.
Can't we used below approach:

except Exception as ex:
    exceptions.handle(request, _('Unable to update 
                                 user password: %s') % ex)
it will handle all exceptions and give user same message on UI as given by keystone.
Thoughts?
But then the error message is not translated.

I think the issue applies to large number of exceptions than what is targeted for this patch i.e. showing less useful info in dashboard than what is actually returned from API.
This approach is right for fixing the issue mentioned but ultimately we need to do this for every exception.
I'm currently working on changing the hard-coded exceptions in horizon to the original msg returned from API.
